Message.Issue: 'LDAPManager.connect(NetworkCredential, bool, bool, bool)' calls into 'DirectoryConnection.Credential.set(NetworkCredential)' which has a LinkDemand. By making this call, 'DirectoryConnection.Credential.set(NetworkCredential)' is indirectly exposed to user code. Review the following call stack that might expose a way to circumvent security protection: ->'LDAPManager.connect(NetworkCredential, bool, bool, bool)' ->'LDAPManager.connect(NetworkCredential, bool, bool, bool)'

'LDAPManager.connect(NetworkCredential, bool, bool, bool)' calls into 'LdapConnection.Bind()' which has a LinkDemand. By making this call, 'LdapConnection.Bind()' is indirectly exposed to user code. Review the following call stack that might expose a way to circumvent security protection: ->'LDAPManager.connect(NetworkCredential, bool, bool, bool)' ->'LDAPManager.connect(NetworkCredential, bool, bool, bool)'

'LDAPManager.connect(NetworkCredential, bool, bool, bool)' calls into 'X509Certificate.Import(string)' which has a LinkDemand. By making this call, 'X509Certificate.Import(string)' is indirectly exposed to user code. Review the following call stack that might expose a way to circumvent security protection: ->'LDAPManager.connect(NetworkCredential, bool, bool, bool)' ->'LDAPManager.connect(NetworkCredential, bool, bool, bool)'

'LDAPUserManipulator.changeUserPassword(LDAPUser, string, out LDAPState)' calls into 'DirectoryConnection.SendRequest(DirectoryRequest)' which has a LinkDemand. By making this call, 'DirectoryConnection.SendRequest(DirectoryRequest)' is indirectly exposed to user code. Review the following call stack that might expose a way to circumvent security protection: ->'LDAPUserManipulator.changeUserPassword(LDAPUser, string, out LDAPState)' ->'LDAPUserManipulator.changeUserPassword(LDAPUser, string, out LDAPState)'

'LDAPUserManipulator.createUser(LDAPUser, out LDAPState, string)' calls into 'DirectoryConnection.SendRequest(DirectoryRequest)' which has a LinkDemand. By making this call, 'DirectoryConnection.SendRequest(DirectoryRequest)' is indirectly exposed to user code. Review the following call stack that might expose a way to circumvent security protection: ->'LDAPUserManipulator.createUser(LDAPUser, out LDAPState, string)' ->'LDAPUserManipulator.createUser(LDAPUser, out LDAPState, string)'

'LDAPUserManipulator.deleteUser(LDAPUser, out LDAPState)' calls into 'DirectoryConnection.SendRequest(DirectoryRequest)' which has a LinkDemand. By making this call, 'DirectoryConnection.SendRequest(DirectoryRequest)' is indirectly exposed to user code. Review the following call stack that might expose a way to circumvent security protection: ->'LDAPUserManipulator.deleteUser(LDAPUser, out LDAPState)' ->'LDAPUserManipulator.deleteUser(LDAPUser, out LDAPState)'

'LDAPUserManipulator.modifyUserAttribute(DirectoryAttributeOperation, LDAPUser, string, string, out LDAPState)' calls into 'DirectoryConnection.SendRequest(DirectoryRequest)' which has a LinkDemand. By making this call, 'DirectoryConnection.SendRequest(DirectoryRequest)' is indirectly exposed to user code. Review the following call stack that might expose a way to circumvent security protection: ->'LDAPUserManipulator.modifyUserAttribute(DirectoryAttributeOperation, LDAPUser, string, string, out LDAPState)' ->'LDAPUserManipulator.modifyUserAttribute(DirectoryAttributeOperation, LDAPUser, string, string, out LDAPState)'

'LDAPUserManipulator.searchUsers(string, string, string, List<string>, string[], out List<LDAPUser>, out LDAPState)' calls into 'DirectoryConnection.SendRequest(DirectoryRequest)' which has a LinkDemand. By making this call, 'DirectoryConnection.SendRequest(DirectoryRequest)' is indirectly exposed to user code. Review the following call stack that might expose a way to circumvent security protection: ->'LDAPUserManipulator.searchUsers(string, string, string, List<string>, string[], out List<LDAPUser>, out LDAPState)' ->'LDAPUserManipulator.searchUsers(string, string, string, List<string>, string[], out List<LDAPUser>, out LDAPState)'

Rule.Name: Do not indirectly expose methods with link demands
Rule.Description: Do not wrap a method protected by a LinkDemand with a method that does not perform a security check. A LinkDemand checks the permissions of the immediate caller rather than checking the permissions of all callers in the call stack. In this case, the permissions of the wrapper method will be checked. If the wrapper method does not, itself, check the permissions of callers higher in the call stack, malicious code might be able to execute the wrapped function even though it lacks permission to do so.
Rule.Resolution: {0} calls into {1} which has a LinkDemand. By making this call, {1} is indirectly exposed to user code. Review the following call stack that might expose a way to circumvent security protection: {2}
